title: How to Eat Hummus

steps.headline: Try the original hummus recipe.
steps.description: Although this is often called “plain” hummus, the classic hummus recipe packs a lot of flavor. Whether you buy already-prepared hummus from the grocery store or you make your own, most classic hummus includes olive oil, garlic, lemon juice, cumin, salt, and tahini, which is a paste made from sesame seeds.

steps.headline: Add roasted red peppers to give your hummus a kick.
steps.description: Roasted red peppers are a little sweet, a little smoky, and lightly spicy. Top hummus with these peppers, chop them up and stir them in, or blend them in when you mash your chickpeas. Try adding a pinch of paprika to make your hummus extra earthy.

steps.headline: Stir in pine nuts, paprika, and olive oil for a rich, buttery flavor.
steps.description: Pine nuts are a great way to dress up store-bought hummus. They have a buttery, slightly sweet flavor which complements chickpeas well. Use high-quality olive oil, lots of pine nuts, and a dash of paprika for a popular variation on the classic.

steps.headline: Make hummus creamy by adding Greek yogurt.
steps.description: In addition to the smooth texture Greek yogurt will give your hummus, it will also add extra protein. This will help you feel full longer, even if you eat less. It will also give you more energy throughout the day. Try this if you’ll be using your hummus as a spread on sandwiches or pitas.

steps.headline: Put a bright twist on hummus by adding in roasted beets.
steps.description: Beets will add an earthy flavor to hummus. They will also turn it a bright shade ranging from pink to deep red, depending on how many beets you add in. Season the dish with feta and dill for a bright, unique flavor.

steps.headline: Mash up avocados and add them to your hummus.
steps.description: Avocados are creamy, so they mix in easily with hummus, and their mild flavor blends well with any of your favorite herbs and spices. In addition, avocado adds additional fiber and monounsaturated fats, making hummus even healthier.

methods.name: Eating Hummus as a Dip or a Spread

steps.headline: Pair hummus with a variety of veggies.
steps.description: No matter what flavor you prefer your hummus, try pairing it with fresh veggies for a healthy snack or lunch. Some popular veggie options include carrot sticks, cucumber, cauliflower, and raw red bell pepper.

steps.headline: Put out an assortment of crackers and chips.
steps.description: Try different textures, sizes, and shapes for variety. Pita chips, bread sticks, ritz crackers, and pretzel sticks all provide a great crunch that pairs well with the creaminess of hummus.

steps.headline: Try a combination of falafel and hummus.
steps.description: Falafel is a fried dish made from chickpeas, and hummus is made of chickpeas, so this is a natural combination. Serve classic hummus alongside the falafel as a dip, or try the version with the pine nuts for a twist.

steps.headline: Spread hummus on a pita or a gyro.
steps.description: Pita bread is the perfect consistency for hummus. It’s thick enough to hold up under the heavy spread, but thin enough that it doesn’t seem dry. Try spreading hummus on a plain pita or add it to a traditional Greek gyro with lamb and tzatziki sauce.

steps.headline: Use as a replacement for mayonnaise on a sandwich.
steps.description: Looking for a healthier condiment to dress your sandwich? Try using hummus instead of mayo. This is especially tasty when the hummus is mixed with Greek yogurt.

steps.headline: Pair hummus with grilled meats.
steps.description: Well-grilled meats, including beef, lamb, and chicken, make a great accompaniment to hummus. Season the meat with lemon, garlic, and spices to complement the flavor of the hummus. Try grilling the meat on kebabs so it will be easy to dip!

steps.headline: Replace the sour cream in mashed potatoes with hummus.
steps.description: Your mashed potatoes will have extra protein and vitamins that it normally lacks, making it a more nutritious side dish. This is great if you’re cooking for someone with a dairy sensitivity!

steps.headline: Toss your pasta with hummus.
steps.description: This unusual technique will create more of a coating for your noodles than a sauce, but you'll love the unique flavor and texture hummus adds to your dish. Try this with a cold pasta salad or as a base for a pesto dish with noodles.

steps.headline: Add hummus to your deviled eggs.
steps.description: Instead of the mayo usually used in deviled eggs, scoop out the yolks from your boiled eggs and mix them with hummus. This is especially delicious with hummus that has avocado added. Top with a sprinkle of paprika.

steps.headline: Make salad dressing with hummus.
steps.description: For a new way to toss your favorite greens, mix hummus into a mixture of olive oil, lemon or lime juice, paprika (or the Middle Eastern spice za'atar), and a little water. This is a great dressing for a salad made with dark greens, including kale, arugula, or baby spinach. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

steps.headline: Top fish or chicken with hummus.
steps.description: When you bake chicken or fish that has been coated in hummus, it develops a light, delicious crust. Fish topped with hummus is a traditional dish, but chicken is delicious when prepared this way as well. This is a great way to pack extra protein and fiber into your dish while making sure it’s full of flavor.

text: Trying Different Types of Hummus Try the original hummus recipe. Although this is often called “plain” hummus, the classic hummus recipe packs a lot of flavor. Whether you buy already-prepared hummus from the grocery store or you make your own, most classic hummus includes olive oil, garlic, lemon juice, cumin, salt, and tahini, which is a paste made from sesame seeds. Add roasted red peppers to give your hummus a kick. Roasted red peppers are a little sweet, a little smoky, and lightly spicy. Top hummus with these peppers, chop them up and stir them in, or blend them in when you mash your chickpeas. Try adding a pinch of paprika to make your hummus extra earthy. Stir in pine nuts, paprika, and olive oil for a rich, buttery flavor. Pine nuts are a great way to dress up store-bought hummus. They have a buttery, slightly sweet flavor which complements chickpeas well. Use high-quality olive oil, lots of pine nuts, and a dash of paprika for a popular variation on the classic. Make hummus creamy by adding Greek yogurt. In addition to the smooth texture Greek yogurt will give your hummus, it will also add extra protein. This will help you feel full longer, even if you eat less. It will also give you more energy throughout the day. Try this if you’ll be using your hummus as a spread on sandwiches or pitas. Put a bright twist on hummus by adding in roasted beets. Beets will add an earthy flavor to hummus. They will also turn it a bright shade ranging from pink to deep red, depending on how many beets you add in. Season the dish with feta and dill for a bright, unique flavor. Mash up avocados and add them to your hummus. Avocados are creamy, so they mix in easily with hummus, and their mild flavor blends well with any of your favorite herbs and spices. In addition, avocado adds additional fiber and monounsaturated fats, making hummus even healthier. Eating Hummus as a Dip or a Spread Pair hummus with a variety of veggies. No matter what flavor you prefer your hummus, try pairing it with fresh veggies for a healthy snack or lunch. Some popular veggie options include carrot sticks, cucumber, cauliflower, and raw red bell pepper. Put out an assortment of crackers and chips. Try different textures, sizes, and shapes for variety. Pita chips, bread sticks, ritz crackers, and pretzel sticks all provide a great crunch that pairs well with the creaminess of hummus. Try a combination of falafel and hummus. Falafel is a fried dish made from chickpeas, and hummus is made of chickpeas, so this is a natural combination. Serve classic hummus alongside the falafel as a dip, or try the version with the pine nuts for a twist. Spread hummus on a pita or a gyro. Pita bread is the perfect consistency for hummus. It’s thick enough to hold up under the heavy spread, but thin enough that it doesn’t seem dry. Try spreading hummus on a plain pita or add it to a traditional Greek gyro with lamb and tzatziki sauce. Use as a replacement for mayonnaise on a sandwich. Looking for a healthier condiment to dress your sandwich? Try using hummus instead of mayo. This is especially tasty when the hummus is mixed with Greek yogurt. Pair hummus with grilled meats. Well-grilled meats, including beef, lamb, and chicken, make a great accompaniment to hummus. Season the meat with lemon, garlic, and spices to complement the flavor of the hummus. Try grilling the meat on kebabs so it will be easy to dip! Adding Hummus to Other Foods Replace the sour cream in mashed potatoes with hummus. Your mashed potatoes will have extra protein and vitamins that it normally lacks, making it a more nutritious side dish. This is great if you’re cooking for someone with a dairy sensitivity! Toss your pasta with hummus. This unusual technique will create more of a coating for your noodles than a sauce, but you'll love the unique flavor and texture hummus adds to your dish. Try this with a cold pasta salad or as a base for a pesto dish with noodles. Add hummus to your deviled eggs. Instead of the mayo usually used in deviled eggs, scoop out the yolks from your boiled eggs and mix them with hummus. This is especially delicious with hummus that has avocado added. Top with a sprinkle of paprika. Make salad dressing with hummus. For a new way to toss your favorite greens, mix hummus into a mixture of olive oil, lemon or lime juice, paprika (or the Middle Eastern spice za'atar), and a little water. This is a great dressing for a salad made with dark greens, including kale, arugula, or baby spinach. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Top fish or chicken with hummus. When you bake chicken or fish that has been coated in hummus, it develops a light, delicious crust. Fish topped with hummus is a traditional dish, but chicken is delicious when prepared this way as well. This is a great way to pack extra protein and fiber into your dish while making sure it’s full of flavor.
